title: Abbreviations
description: Test your knowledge of abbreviation rules and conventions in Canadian English writing

questions.question: What is the correct way to introduce an abbreviation for the first time in a document?
options: Write the full term followed by the abbreviation in parentheses
Use the abbreviation followed by the full term in brackets
questions.explanation: When using an abbreviation for the first time, write the full term followed by the abbreviation in parentheses. Example: The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) announced...

questions.question: Abbreviations of single words generally take periods (e.g., govt., dept., Sept.).
questions.explanation: True. Abbreviations of single words generally take periods. Examples include govt., dept., Sept., etc.

questions.question: What is the correct plural form of 'p.' (page)?
questions.explanation: The correct plural of p. (page) is pp. (pages). Other examples: l. → ll. (lines), f. → ff. (following pages).

questions.question: SI/metric symbols should take a plural 's' when representing multiple units (e.g., 5 cms, 75 kgs).
questions.explanation: False. SI/metric symbols maintain the same form for both singular and plural: 5 cm (not 5 cms), 75 kg (not 75 kgs).

questions.question: What is the correct plural form of 'Mr.'?
questions.explanation: The plural of Mr. is Messrs. This is used when addressing multiple men. Similarly, the plural of Mrs. is Mmes.

questions.question: How should you write a military rank like 'Lieutenant-Colonel'?
questions.explanation: Military ranks with hyphens in the full form retain the hyphen in abbreviation: Lt.-Col. (Lieutenant-Colonel), Lt.-Cmdr. (Lieutenant-Commander).

questions.question: It is correct to write 'Dr. Jane Smith, Ph.D.' when listing someone with a doctorate.
questions.explanation: False. Use either the title (Dr. Jane Smith) OR the degree (Jane Smith, Ph.D.), but not both together. They represent the same credential.

questions.question: How should you write 'British Columbia' in formal body text?
options: Spell out British Columbia in running text, use BC in addresses
questions.explanation: In formal documents, spell out province and territory names in running text. Use abbreviations like BC primarily in addresses, tables, and lists.

questions.question: What is the correct way to abbreviate 'Street' in an address?
questions.explanation: The standard abbreviation for Street in addresses is St. Other common abbreviations: Ave. (Avenue), Rd. (Road), Blvd. (Boulevard).

questions.question: How should degrees of latitude be written?
questions.explanation: Latitude and longitude are written with the degree symbol directly attached to the number, followed by the direction with no space: 45°N, 75°W.

questions.question: What is the correct abbreviation for 'chapter' when citing specific chapters?
questions.explanation: The standard abbreviation for chapter is ch. or c. Example: See ch. 3, p. 45.

questions.question: What does the abbreviation 'i.e.' mean?
questions.explanation: i.e. means 'that is' (Latin: id est). It's used to clarify or rephrase. For 'for example,' use e.g. (exempli gratia).

questions.question: Which of the following Latin abbreviations are used correctly? (Select all that apply)
options: The report discusses three topics, i.e., climate, economy, and health
The study found significant results, e.g. improved performance
questions.explanation: Correct uses: c. (circa) for 'approximately', cf. (confer) for 'compare', e.g. (exempli gratia) for 'for example'. However, i.e. means 'that is' (for clarification), not for listing multiple examples - that should be e.g.

questions.question: Scientific abbreviations like DNA, RNA, and pH should be spelled out on first use.
questions.explanation: False. Well-established scientific abbreviations like DNA, RNA, pH, and IQ are so widely recognized that they don't need to be spelled out.

questions.question: How should you write a company name like 'General Motors Corporation'?
options: Write the full name on first use, then use the abbreviation
questions.explanation: For corporate names, write the full legal name on first mention, followed by any commonly used abbreviation in parentheses, then use the abbreviation in subsequent references.

questions.question: What is the difference between an acronym and an initialism?
options: There is no difference; they are the same thing
Acronyms are pronounced as words (NATO), initialisms are pronounced letter by letter (FBI)
Initialisms are only used for organizations
questions.explanation: Acronyms are pronounced as words (NATO, radar, scuba), while initialisms are pronounced letter by letter (FBI, CBC, RCMP).

questions.question: It is correct to write 'Enter your PIN number' when asking for a personal identification number.
questions.explanation: False. This creates redundancy since PIN already means 'Personal Identification Number.' Write either 'Enter your PIN' or 'Enter your personal identification number,' but not both.

questions.question: How should you abbreviate 'numbers' in body text?
questions.explanation: In body text, use No. for 'number' and Nos. for 'numbers.' The # symbol is reserved for tabular and statistical material. Example: Nos. 56-86 are missing.

questions.question: When should you use the % symbol instead of spelling out 'percent'?
options: Use % in technical, financial, and statistical documents
Only use % in charts and graphs
questions.explanation: Use the % symbol in economic, financial, statistical, or technical documents where figures are abundant. In general text, spell out 'percent' except when used adjectivally (e.g., a 15% bond).

questions.question: The ampersand (&) should be used in federal department names like 'Public Works & Government Services.'
questions.explanation: False. Do NOT use the ampersand in federal department names. Write 'Public Works and Government Services.' Use & only when it's part of an official corporate name (e.g., AT&T, Smith & Jones).

questions.question: How should you distinguish Canadian dollars from US dollars in a document?
options: Use $ for both and clarify in text
Use C$ or CAN$ for Canadian, US$ for American
questions.explanation: Use C$ or CAN$ for Canadian dollars and US$ for US dollars when you need to distinguish between currencies. Example: The loan will be repaid in instalments of C$650 each.

questions.question: Which statements about abbreviating months are correct? (Select all that apply)
options: Always spell out month names in body text and footnotes
June and July are abbreviated only in military writing
All months can be abbreviated in tables and forms
questions.explanation: All three statements are correct: spell out months in body text and footnotes; May is never abbreviated; June and July are shortened only in military writing; most months can be abbreviated in tables and forms.

questions.question: What is the correct format for elapsed time?
questions.explanation: For elapsed time, use colons with no spaces: 2:30:21 (hours:minutes:seconds). You can add decimal fractions: 2:30:21.65 (hours:minutes:seconds.tenths.hundredths).

questions.question: How should time zone abbreviations be written?
options: Either capitals or lowercase is acceptable
questions.explanation: Time zone abbreviations use all capitals without periods when used with a specific time: 4:30 p.m. EST, 7:15 a.m. MST. Write out in full (lowercase) when used generally: Pacific standard time.

questions.question: SI symbols should be followed by a period, except at the end of a sentence.
questions.explanation: False. SI symbols are NEVER followed by periods, except when they occur at the end of a sentence. Write '5 kg' (not '5 kg.') in the middle of a sentence, but 'The box weighs 5 kg.' at the end.

questions.question: How should you write '5 centimetres'?
questions.explanation: The correct form is '5 cm' - with a space between the numeral and symbol, no period, and no plural 's'. SI symbols never take periods (except at sentence end) or plural forms.

questions.question: What is the SI unit symbol for pressure and stress?
questions.explanation: Pascal (Pa) is the SI unit for pressure and stress. Newton (N) is force, joule (J) is energy, and watt (W) is power.

questions.question: What is the correct way to write 'kilometres per hour'?
questions.explanation: When combining SI symbols with time or division, use an oblique (/): km/h (not kmh or kph). Other examples: r/min (not rpm), J/kg (not Jkg).

questions.question: How should you write 'square feet' using imperial abbreviations?
questions.explanation: In the imperial system, use 'sq.' for square and 'cu.' for cubic, with a space before the unit: 100 sq. ft., 20 cu. yd. Note the space between sq./cu. and the following abbreviation.

questions.question: Which business abbreviations are appropriate for use in tables and forms? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: All of these are appropriate business abbreviations for tables and forms: CEO, qty., recd., V.P. However, in formal business letters, spell out these terms fully.
